questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not associated with the clinical presentation shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ciprofloxacin

 

Option B:

  • The given picture is of Cornea Verticillata.
  • It is a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium seen in patients on long-term treatment with medication such as
    • Amiodarone
    • Chloroquine
    • Phenothiazine
    • Indomethacin
  • The condition is generally asymptomatic, harmless and reversible on stopping the drug.
  • The whorl-like pattern shows the direction of migration of corneal epithelial cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amiodarone is a medication used for certain types of cardiac arrhythmias. One of its known side effects is cornea verticillata. The deposits are usually asymptomatic and do not typically necessitate discontinuation of the medication.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that can cause cornea verticillata. The deposits are again usually asymptomatic but can be a consideration in long-term treatment with chlorpromazine.

 

Option D. Indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), has been associated with the development of cornea verticillata. Like the other drugs listed, these deposits are typically asymptomatic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of drugs causing cornea verticillata, ciprofloxacin does not typically lead to this condition, unlike amiodarone, chlorpromazine, and indomethacin, which are known to cause vortex keratopathy as a side effect.

 

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 220

questions.text: Name the procedure shown:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keratoplasty

 

Option C: Keratoplasty – corneal grafting or transplantation, is a procedure in which patient’s diseased cornea is replaced by donor’s healthy cornea.

 

Types:

 

  1. Full thickness (Penetrating)
  2. Lamellar (Partial Thickness)
  3. Small Patch Graft

 

Indications:

 

  1. Optical: to improve vision. Important indications are: corneal opacity, bullous keratopathy, corneal dystrophies, advanced keratoconus.
  2. Therapeutic: to replace inflamed cornea not responding to conventional therapy.
  3. Tectonic graft: to restore integrity of eyeball e.g. after corneal perforation and in marked corneal thinning.
  4. Cosmetic: to improve the appearance of the eye.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. LASIK (Laser-Assisted In Situ Keratomileusis): A refractive surgery where a laser reshapes the cornea to correct vision problems like myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism.

 

Option B. Small Incision Cataract Surgery: A modern cataract removal technique involving a small incision through which the clouded lens is emulsified with ultrasound and removed, followed by the implantation of an intraocular lens.

 

Option D. Fasanella-Servat Procedure: A surgical technique used to correct mild to moderate ptosis by shortening the levator muscle or Müller's muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of corneal interrupted sutures and central donor corneal button is indicative of keratoplasty.

choices.text: Gross examination + Slit Lamp examination
Gross examination + Slit lamp + Specular microscopy.

questions.text: What is the proper tissue evaluation of donor cornea done with?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gross examination + Slit lamp + Specular microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cornea is inspected grossly with a torch.
  • Slit lamp biomicroscopy to evaluate – epithelial defects, folds, etc.
  • Specular microscopy- corneal endothelial count & morphology.

 

 

Ref: pg 561/ Eye banking/ PEYMAN’S principle & practise of ophthalmology/ 2nd edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a late complication of keratoplasty?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Graft Rejection

 

Option D:

 

Early complications:

 

  • Flat AC
  • Infection
  • Iris prolapse
  • Graft failure

 

Late complications: 

 

  • Graft rejection
  • Astigmatism

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flat Anterior Chamber: This is usually an early complication following keratoplasty. It occurs when the space between the cornea and the iris is diminished, often due to leakage of aqueous humor from the eye.

 

 

Option B. Iris Prolapse: This is another early complication that can occur post-keratoplasty. It involves the protrusion of the iris through an incision or wound in the eye. Iris prolapse typically happens soon after surgery due to improper wound healing or increased intraocular pressure.

 

Option C. Infection: While infection can occur at any time after surgery, it is often considered an early complication in the context of keratoplasty. Post-surgical infections are typically acute and arise due to intraoperative contamination or early postoperative care issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graft rejection is a late complication of keratoplasty, characterized by the immune system's reaction to the donor cornea, potentially occurring months to year’s post-surgery.

 

 

Ref: pg 137/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corneal Tattooing

 

Option D: Keratopigmentation or corneal tattooing is a procedure used for centuries to improve the cosmetic appearance of corneal scars and leukomas.

 

Keratopigmentation has been used to also treat visual symptoms associated with corneal and iris abnormalities.

 

 

Micronized mineral pigments are new pigments that have been shown to produce good cosmetic appearance without an inflammatory response and ocular toxicity.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Keratoplasty: A surgical procedure to replace part or all of a damaged or diseased cornea with healthy donor corneal tissue.

 

 

Option B. LASIK (Laser-Assisted In Situ Keratomileusis): A laser surgery technique used to correct refractive errors such as myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism by reshaping the cornea.

 

 

Option C. Phacoemulsification: A modern cataract surgery technique where ultrasonic vibrations are used to emulsify and remove the cloudy lens, typically followed by the insertion of an intraocular lens (IOL).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corneal Tattooing: A procedure used to improve the cosmetic appearance of an eye with a disfigured cornea, involving the insertion of pigment into the corneal stroma.

 

 

Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Eye_Tattooing#cite_note

questions.text: Which among the following is a biological glue used as an alternative to suture in surgical procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibrin

 

Option B:

 

  • Tissue adhesives are used as an alternative to suture.
  • 2 types:
    • Biological – fibrin
    • Synthetic- cyanoacrylate, polyethylene glycol

 

 Uses:

 

  • Conjunctival closure following pterygium                     
  • Amniotic membrane transplantation
  • Lamellar corneal grafting
  • Closure of corneal perforations
  • Strabismus surgery

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cyanoacrylate, is a synthetic adhesive, commonly known as "superglue." It is used in medical applications for wound closure but is not a biological material. Cyanoacrylates rapidly polymerize in the presence of water or tissue fluids, forming a strong bond that can hold tissues together. However, due to its synthetic nature, it's not classified as biological glue.

 

Option C. Polyethylene Glycol (PEG) is a synthetic polymer that is used in various medical applications, including as a component in some surgical sealants. However, it's not biological glue in itself. PEG-based hydrogels may be used in tissue engineering and drug delivery, but they don't function as biological glues like fibrin.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option would be incorrect as fibrin (option B) is indeed biological glue used in surgical procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrin is the biological glue used as an alternative to sutures in surgical procedures, offering a biocompatible and natural way to aid in tissue adhesion and healing.

 

 

Ref:  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2804126/

questions.text: What is Fibrin glue made up of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both of the above

 

Option C: Fibrin glue is a biological tissue adhesive which imitates the final stages of the coagulation cascade when a solution of human fibrinogen is activated by thrombin (the two components of fibrin glue).

 

Fibrin glue includes a fibrinogen component and a thrombin component, both prepared by processing plasma.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Human Fibrinogen is a protein produced by the liver, circulating in the blood. When tissues are injured, fibrinogen is converted into fibrin during the blood clotting process, which helps to stop bleeding and initiate healing. In fibrin glue, fibrinogen is one of the key components.

 

Option B. Thrombin is an enzyme that plays a critical role in blood coagulation. It converts soluble fibrinogen into insoluble fibrin. In the context of fibrin glue, thrombin is mixed with fibrinogen; when these two components are combined, thrombin catalyzes the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin, forming a fibrin clot that acts as a tissue adhesive.

 

Option D. Cyanoacrylate, is a different type of tissue adhesive, commonly known as "superglue." Cyanoacrylate glues are not made of biological materials but are synthetic and work by rapidly polymerizing in the presence of water (or tissue fluids), creating a strong bond to hold tissues together. They are used in different clinical scenarios compared to fibrin glues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrin glue is composed of human fibrinogen and thrombin, which, when mixed, form a fibrin clot that acts as a tissue adhesive, unlike cyanoacrylate, a synthetic adhesive.

 

 

Ref: //www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2804126/

questions.text: Which of the following solutions is used for corneal storage purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MK Medium

 

Option D: MK medium (McCarey Kaufman) is used for storing corneal donor tissue for 7 to 10 days.

 

Others: Optisol, Dexsol, K sol, etc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While normal saline is often used in medical settings for various purposes, including as an irrigation solution or for intravenous administration, it is not ideal for the storage of corneal tissues. It lacks the necessary nutrients and balanced pH required to maintain the viability of corneal cells during storage.

 

Option B. 1% Gentamycin is an antibiotic and is used to prevent bacterial infections. While it might be used to prevent contamination of corneal tissues, it is not a storage medium. Alone, it does not provide the necessary environment to preserve the viability and function of corneal cells.

 

Option C. 0.3% Formaldehyde is a preservative and a disinfectant but is not suitable for the storage of living tissues like the cornea. It is used in tissue fixation for histological purposes because it preserves tissue structure by cross-linking proteins, but this process also kills the cells, making it unsuitable for corneal storage where the goal is to keep the cells alive and functional.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For corneal storage purposes, MK (Moore's-Kaufman) medium is the appropriate solution, as it provides the necessary nutrients and environmental conditions to maintain the viability of corneal tissues.

 

 

Ref: pg 563/ eye banking/PEYMAN’S principle & practise of ophthalmology/ 2nd edition
